{{Use Indian English|date=January 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox organization | image = TERI India Habitat Center Delhi.jpg | caption = TERI Headquarters at the [[India Habitat Centre]] (IHC), [[Lodhi Road]], [[New Delhi]] | logo = [[File:The Energy and Resources Institute logo.png|150px|TERI logo]] | type = [[Non Profit]] [[Research]] [[Institution]] | leader_title = Director General | leader_name = Dr. Ajay Mathur<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teriin.org/profile/ajay-mathur|title=Dr Ajay Mathur - TERI|website=www.teriin.org}}</ref> | name = The Energy and Resources Institute - TERI | established = 1974 | location = [[New Delhi]], India | website = {{URL|http://www.teriin.org/}} | mission = ''We will work towards global sustainable development, creating innovative solutions for a better tomorrow'' | founder = Darbari S Seth<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.teriin.org/themes/teriday/teri-day-inner-new.php |title=Archived copy |access-date=25 May 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160530203807/http://www.teriin.org/themes/teriday/teri-day-inner-new.php |archive-date=30 May 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> }}
'''The Energy and Resources Institute''' (TERI) is a [[research institute]] based in [[New Delhi]] that conducts research work in the fields of energy, environment and sustainable development. Established in 1974, it was formerly known as Tata Energy and Research Institute. As the scope of its activities widened, it was renamed The Energy and Resources Institute in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.financialexpress.com/archive/teri-stays-teri-but-says-ta-ta-to-tata/70815/|title=Teri Stays Teri, But Says Ta-Ta To Tata|date=|publisher=Financialexpress.com|accessdate=2003-01-22}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Bombay House, Tata Group Headquarters in Mumbai.jpg|thumb|right|[[Bombay House]] the head office of Tata Group from where TERI started operations]]
The origins of TERI lie in [[Mithapur]], a remote town in [[Gujarat]], where a TATA engineer, Darbari Seth, was concerned about the enormous quantities of energy his factory spent on [[desalination]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/teri-championing-the-green-alternative/articleshow/5420185.cms?from=mdr |title=Championing the green alternative |publisher=Economic Times |date=2 January 2010 }}</ref> He proposed the idea of a research institute to tackle the depletion of natural resources and energy scarcity. [[J. R. D. Tata]], chairman of the [[Tata Group|TATA Group]], liked the idea and accepted the proposal. TERI was set up with a modest corpus of 35 million rupees.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.teriin.org/themes/teriday/pdf/5-DSMLecture2006Fifth.pdf |title=Darbari Seth Memorial Lecture 2006 | date=February 2013}}</ref> On the invitation of the then Prime Minister [[Indira Gandhi]], TERI was registered in Delhi in 1974 as the Tata Energy Research Institute.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://envfor.nic.in/envis/compendium/21-teri.pdf |title=ENVIS Centre on Renewable Energy and Environment}}</ref>
==Locations== TERI initially began its operations in the [[Bombay House]], Mumbai, headquarters of [[Tata Group|Tata]]. In 1984, it moved to Delhi where it continued to operate out on the rented premises (which included the [[India International Centre]] ) for almost a decade. In 1993, the organization set up its permanent base in Darbari Seth Block, named after its founder, in the [[India Habitat Centre]] complex located at Lodhi Road, New Delhi. Today TERI has a global presence with many centres in India and abroad.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teriin.org/network-linkages | title=Location and Linkages - TERI | date=15 November 2014 }}</ref> *Headquarters at the [[India Habitat Center]], New Delhi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiahabitat.org/institutions|title=India Habitat Centre - Publication|first=India Habitat|last=Centre|website=www.indiahabitat.org}}</ref> *Southern Regional Centre, [[Bangalore]] *Western Regional Centre, [[Goa]] *North - Eastern Regional Centre, [[Guwahati]] *Himalayan Centre, [[Mukteshwar]] *TERI Mumbai, [[Navi Mumbai]] *TERI Japan, [[Tokyo]] *TERI North America, [[Washington D.C.]] *TERI Europe, [[London]] *TERI South East Asia, Kuala Lumpur, [[Malaysia]]
In October 2011, [[Princess Máxima of the Netherlands]] opened the European headquarters of TERI in [[Utrecht]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uu.nl/en/research/asia |title=Asia - Research - Universiteit Utrecht |date=2011-10-05 }}</ref>
TERI established a research base in Africa to provide technical assistance as well as to facilitate exchange of knowledge amongst the communities in various African states.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://teriafrica.org/about.php |title=TERI Africa }}</ref>
In 2016-17, TERI set up the world's biggest facility for Mycorrhiza production in Gual Pahari, Gurugram,Haryana.
==Staff==
TERI has over 1250 employees, with research professionals from disciplines pertaining to issues of environment and energy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teriin.org/people/committee-of-directors |title=Committee of Directors - TERI}}</ref> The Institute's present Director General is Dr Ajay Mathur.
==Activities== The scope of the organisation's activities includes climate change, energy efficiency, renewable energy, biotechnology, and social transformation.
* [[World Sustainable Development Summit (WSDS)]] - An annual summit which facilitates the exchange of knowledge on diverse aspects of global sustainable development. * [http://labl.teriin.org/ LaBL] (Lighting a Billion Lives) - An initiative to provide clean lighting access to bottom of the pyramid communities. * Green Olympiad<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/meerut/TERI-to-host-Green-Olympiad-for-CBSE-students/articleshow/52094827.cms|title=TERI to host Green Olympiad for CBSE students - Times of India|access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> - Conducted in association with MoEF, it is an international environment examination that is annually organized for middle and high-school students.
==Awards== *Ranked 2 in the list of worlds best climate think tank by international centre for climate governance. *Ranked 20 in the list of top global think tanks according to a survey conducted by [[Think Tanks and Civil Societies Program]] (TTCSP) of University of Pennsylvania, Brookings Institution<ref>{{cite news| url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/5-Indian-thinktanks-in-worlds-top-150-Survey/articleshow/29473323.cms | work= Times of India | title =5 Indian thinktanks in world’s top 150 | date=28 January 2014}}</ref> *Awarded EDF Pulse Award in Paris by the Chairman of EDF Mr Henri Proglio on 30 April 2014, which recognizes ingenious efforts towards providing access to electricity.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://pulse.edf.com/en/les-prix-edf-pulse-le-sourire-des-laureats | work=EDF PULSE | title=EDF PULSE AWARDS: SMILES ALL ROUND | date=30 April 2014}}</ref> *TERI's community radio service Kumaon Vani received an award from the Union Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (I&B) at National Community Radio Sammelan held on 21 March 2014.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=104593 | work=Press Information Bureau, Government of India | title=National Community Radio Awards 2014 presented | date=13 March 2014}}</ref> *TERI's film, The 'Flight' and 'Are we ready to dig in?' won awards at the [[CMS VATAVARAN]] 2014 on 2 February 2014.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://cmsvatavaran.org/awardees2014.php | work=CMS Vatavaran | title=7th CMS VATAVARAN Environment and Wildlife Film Festival and Forum 2013 | date=2 February 2014}}</ref> *Awarded the [[Project Management Institute]] (PMI) Project of Year (2013) award in the NGO category for LaBL project.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.pmi.org.in/events/media/media-files/projectman-06edd6c793bf26f.pdf | work=PMI awards | title=PMI’s Prestigious Project Management Award 2013 | date=27 September 2013}}</ref> *Ranked as the topmost global think-tank in 2013 in the field of climate sciences and research by the International Center for Climate Governance (ICCG)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/eco-news/teri-tops-global-climate-think-tank-list_861305.html|title=TERI tops global climate think-tank list|date=10 July 2013|work=Zee News}}</ref>
==Publications== TERI Press, TERI's publishing arm releases a plethora of publications out of which some noteworthy publications are :
*'''TerraGreen''' - Monthly magazine of TERI on issues of environment, biodiversity, livelihood rights, wildlife, energy, and sustainable development. *'''TERI Energy Data Directory and Yearbook''' ('''TEDDY''') : Launched in 1986, it is a compilation of energy and environment data. It is a comprehensive reference document and a source of information on energy supply sectors (coal and lignite, oil and gas, power, and renewable energy sources) as well as energy-consuming sectors (agriculture, industry, transport, residential, and commercial sectors).<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/global-think-tank-teri-launches-its-annual-publication-teri-energy-data-directory-and-yearbook-teddy-199512091.html| title=Global Think Tank TERI Launches its Annual Publication "TERI Energy Data Directory and Yearbook (TEDDY)" | date=22 March 2013}}</ref> *'''Mycorrhiza News'''- Quarterly newsletter of Mycorrhiza Network.
==GRIHA== Green Rating for Integrated Habitat Assessment (GRIHA)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pcmcindia.gov.in/green_building_about.php|title=About GRIHA (Green Rating for Integrated Habitat Assessment) - PCMC|last=|first=|date=|website=Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation|publisher=Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation|access-date=}}</ref> was conceived by TERI and developed with [[Ministry of New and Renewable Energy]], is a national rating system for [[green buildings]] in India.<ref>{{cite web|author=Business Standard |url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/teri-launches-rating-system-for-green-buildings-107110100057_1.html |title=TERI launches rating system for 'green' buildings |publisher=Business-standard.com |date=2007-11-01 |accessdate=2013-02-02}}</ref>
==TERI School of Advanced Studies== [[TERI School of Advanced Studies]] was established on 19 August 1998, and was recognised by the University Grants Commission (UGC) as a deemed-to-be University in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://delhi.gov.in/DoIT/DoIT_HE/list.pdf |title=List of UGC Recognized University in NCT of Delhi |publisher=delhi.gov.in}}</ref> Set-up as the TERI School of Advanced Studies in 1998, the institution was subsequently renamed TERI University.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/todays-paper/tp-economy/article1748147.ece |title=University status for TERI School |publisher=thehindubusinessline.com}}</ref>
==TERI Prakriti School== Established in January 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiablooms.com/ibns_new/health-details/E/662/teri-launches-prakriti-school-to-focus-on-environment-education.html |title=TERI launches Prakriti School to focus on environment education| publisher=India Blooms}}</ref> with a vision to provide sustainability education and help create environmental awareness among children at an early age. Inaugurated by Union Minister for Environment and Forests [[Prakash Javadekar]], the K-12 school is affiliated to CBSE.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-01-09/news/57883677_1_green-buildings-climate-change-prakash-javadekar |title=Government planning to introduce logo for green buildings: Prakash Javadekar |publisher=Economic Times}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Rajendra K. Pachauri]] * [[World Sustainable Development Summit (WSDS)]] * [[TERI University]] * [[TERI-Deakin Nanobiotechnology Centre]]

{{unreferenced|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox park | name = Wetlands Institute | image = Wetlands Institute, Stone Harbor, NJ - looking north.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = Wetlands Institute in 2018 | map = USA New Jersey Cape May County#New Jersey#USA | map_width = | type = | location = 1075 Stone Harbor Boulevard
[[Stone Harbor, New Jersey]] | nearest_city = | coordinates = {{WikidataCoord|display=inline}} | area = | created = | operator = | visitation_num = | status = | designation = | open = | website = {{Official URL}} }} '''The Wetlands Institute''' is a [[non-profit organization]] started in 1969 by the executive director of [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]], Herbert Mills. The Wetlands Institute sits on 6,000 [[acre]]s (24 km²) of protected [[wetlands]] in [[Stone Harbor, New Jersey]].{{cite web|title=History of The Wetlands Institute|url=https://wetlandsinstitute.org/about-us/overview/history/|publisher=The Wetlands Institute}} It hosts educational tours and courses and is a base for research on wetlands [[ecology]]. It is home to the annual Wings 'n Water art festival. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Nature centers in New Jersey}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wetlands Institute}} [[Category:Nature centers in New Jersey]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Cape May County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Cape May County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Protected areas of Cape May County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Stone Harbor, New Jersey]] {{environmental-org-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Chembox | Name = Trihydrogen cation | ImageFile = Trihydrogen-cation-3D-vdW.png | ImageSize = | ImageName = [[Space-filling model]] of the {{chem|H|3|+}} cation | Section1 = {{Chembox Identifiers | CASNo = 28132-48-1 | RTECS = }} | Section2 = {{Chembox Properties | Formula = {{chem|H|3|+}} | MolarMass = 3.02 | Appearance = | Density = | Solubility = | MeltingPt = | BoilingPt = | ConjugateBase = [[Dihydrogen]] }} | Section3 = {{Chembox Structure | Coordination = }} | Section7 = {{Chembox Hazards | EUClass = | RPhrases = | SPhrases = | NFPA-H = | NFPA-F = | NFPA-R = | FlashPt = }} | Section8 = {{Chembox Related | OtherAnions = [[hydride]] | OtherCations = [[hydrogen ion]], [[dihydrogen cation]], [[hydrogen ion cluster]] | OtherCompounds = [[trihydrogen]] }} }}
The '''trihydrogen cation''', also known as '''protonated molecular hydrogen''' or '''{{chem|H|3|+}}''', is one of the most abundant [[ion]]s in the universe. It is stable in the [[interstellar medium]] (ISM) due to the low temperature and low density of interstellar space. The role that {{chem|H|3|+}} plays in the gas-phase chemistry of the ISM is unparalleled by any other molecular ion. The [[cation]] is also the simplest triatomic [[molecule]], since its two electrons are the only valence electrons in the system. It is also the simplest example of a [[three-center two-electron bond]] system.
==History== {{chem|H|3|+}} was first discovered by [[J. J. Thomson]] in 1911.<ref name="elecrays">{{cite journal |last=Thomson |first=J. J. |date=1913 |title=Rays of Positive Electricity |journal=[[Proceedings of the Royal Society A]] |volume=89 |issue=607 |pages=1–20 |doi=10.1098/rspa.1913.0057 |bibcode = 1913RSPSA..89....1T }}</ref> While studying the resultant species of [[plasma (physics)|plasma]] discharges, he discovered something very odd. Using an early form of [[mass spectrometry]], he discovered a large abundance of a [[molecular]] ion with a [[mass-to-charge ratio]] of 3. He stated that the only two possibilities were C<sup>4+</sup> or {{chem|H|3|+}}. Since C<sup>4+</sup> would be very unlikely and the signal grew stronger in pure [[hydrogen]] gas, he correctly assigned the species as {{chem|H|3|+}}.
The formation pathway was discovered by Hogness & Lunn in 1925.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Hogness |first=T. R. |author2=Lunn, E. G. |date=1925 |title=The Ionization of Hydrogen by Electron Impact as Interpreted by Positive Ray Analysis |journal=[[Physical Review]] |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=44–55 |doi=10.1103/PhysRev.26.44 |bibcode = 1925PhRv...26...44H }}</ref> They also used an early form of mass spectrometry to study hydrogen discharges. They found that as the pressure of hydrogen increased, the amount of {{chem|H|3|+}} increased linearly and the amount of {{chem|H|2|+}} decreased linearly. In addition, there was little H<sup>+</sup> at any pressure. This data suggested the [[proton]] exchange formation pathway discussed below.
In 1961, Martin ''et al.'' first suggested that {{chem|H|3|+}} may be present in interstellar space given the large amount of hydrogen in interstellar space and its reaction pathway was [[exothermic]] (~1.5 [[Electronvolt|eV]]).<ref name="occurrence">{{cite journal |last=Martin |first=D. W. |author2=McDaniel, E. W. |author3=Meeks, M. L. |date=1961 |title=On the Possible Occurrence of {{chem|H|3|+}} in Interstellar Space |journal=[[Astrophysical Journal]] |volume=134 |page=1012 |doi= 10.1086/147232|bibcode=1961ApJ...134.1012M}}</ref> This led to the suggestion of Watson and Herbst & Klemperer in 1973 that {{chem|H|3|+}} is responsible for the formation of many observed molecular ions.<ref name="Watson1973">{{cite journal |last=Watson |first=W. D. |date=1973 |title=The Rate of Formation of Interstellar Molecules by Ion-Molecule Reactions |journal=Astrophysical Journal |volume=183 |issue=2 |pages=L17 |doi=10.1086/181242 |bibcode=1973ApJ...183L..17W}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Herbst |first=E. |author2=Klemperer, W. |date=1973 |title=The Formation and Depletion of Molecules in Dense Interstellar Clouds |journal=Astrophysical Journal |volume=185 |page=505 |doi=10.1086/152436 |bibcode=1973ApJ...185..505H}}</ref>
It was not until 1980 that the first spectrum of {{chem|H|3|+}} was discovered by Takeshi Oka,<ref name="Oka1980">{{cite journal |last=Oka |first=T. |date=1980 |title=Observation of the Infrared Spectrum of {{chem|H|3|+}} |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=45 |issue= 7|pages=531–534 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.45.531 |bibcode=1980PhRvL..45..531O}}</ref> which was of the ν<sub>2</sub> fundamental band using a technique called [[frequency modulation]] detection. This started the search for interstellar {{chem|H|3|+}}. [[Emission line]]s were detected in the late 1980s and early 1990s in the [[ionosphere]]s of [[Jupiter]], [[Saturn]], and [[Uranus]].<ref name="Drossart1989">{{cite journal |last=Drossart |first=P. |display-authors=etal |date=1989 |title=Detection of {{chem|H|3|+}} on Jupiter |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=340 |issue=6234 |page=539 |doi=10.1038/340539a0 |bibcode = 1989Natur.340..539D }}</ref><ref name="Geballe1993">{{cite journal |last=Geballe |first=T. R. |display-authors=etal |date=1993 |title=Detection of {{chem|H|3|+}} Infrared Emission Lines in Saturn |journal=Astrophysical Journal |volume=408 |issue=2 |pages=L109 |doi=10.1086/186843 |bibcode=1993ApJ...408L.109G}}</ref><ref name="Trafton1993">{{cite journal |last=Trafton |first=L. M. |display-authors=etal |date=1993 |title=Detection of {{chem|H|3|+}} from Uranus |journal=Astrophysical Journal |volume=405 |page=761 |doi=10.1086/172404 |bibcode=1993ApJ...405..761T}}</ref>
In 1996, {{chem|H|3|+}} was finally detected in the interstellar medium (ISM) by Geballe & Oka in two molecular [[interstellar clouds]] in the sightlines GL2136 and W33A.<ref name="Geballe1996">{{cite journal |last=Geballe |first=T. R. |author2=Oka, T. |date=1996 |title=Detection of {{chem|H|3|+}} in Interstellar Space |journal=Nature |volume=384 |issue=6607 |pages=334–335 |doi=10.1038/384334a0 |pmid=8934516 |bibcode = 1996Natur.384..334G }}</ref> In 1998, {{chem|H|3|+}} was unexpectedly detected by McCall ''et al.'' in a diffuse interstellar cloud in the sightline [[Cygnus OB2-12|Cygnus OB2#12]].<ref name="McCall1998">{{cite journal |last=McCall |first=B. J. |display-authors=etal |date=1998 |title=Detection of {{chem|H|3|+}} in the Diffuse Interstellar Medium Toward Cygnus OB2 No. 12 |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=279 |issue=5358 |pages=1910–1913 |doi=10.1126/science.279.5358.1910 |bibcode = 1998Sci...279.1910M }}</ref> In 2006 Oka announced that {{chem|H|3|+}} was ubiquitous in interstellar medium, and that the [[Central Molecular Zone]] contained a million times the concentration of ISM generally.<ref>PNAS, 2006</ref>
== Structure == [[File:H3cation struct.png|thumb|right|150px|The structure of {{chem|H|3|+}}]] [[File:Trihydrogen-cation-MO-diagram.svg|thumb|380px|The [[MO diagram]] of the trihydrogen cation.]] The three hydrogen atoms in the molecule form an [[equilateral triangle]], with a [[bond length]] of 0.90 [[Ångström|Å]] on each side. The bonding among the atoms is a [[three-center two-electron bond|three-centre two-electron bond]], a [[delocalized]] resonance hybrid type of structure. The strength of the bond has been calculated to be around 4.5 [[electronvolt|eV]] (104 kcal/mol).<ref>{{cite journal |last=McCall |first=B. J. |display-authors=etal |date=2004 |title=Dissociative Recombination of Rotationally Cold {{chem|H|3|+}} |journal=Physical Review A |volume=70 |issue=5 |page=052716 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.70.052716 |bibcode = 2004PhRvA..70e2716M }}</ref>
==Formation== <!--The information for this section was from a paper by Eric Herbst.-->The main pathway for the production of {{chem|H|3|+}} is by the reaction of [[Dihydrogen cation|{{chem|H|2|+}}]] and H<sub>2</sub>.<ref name="eherbstastro">{{cite journal |last=Herbst |first=E. |date=2000 |title=The Astrochemistry of {{chem|H|3|+}} |journal=[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A]]|volume=358 |issue=1774 |pages=2523–2534 |doi=10.1098/rsta.2000.0665 }}</ref>
:{{chem|H|2|+}} + H<sub>2</sub> → {{chem|H|3|+}} + H
The concentration of {{chem|H|2|+}} is what limits the rate of this reaction in nature: the only known natural source of it is via ionization of H<sub>2</sub> by a [[cosmic ray]] in interstellar space by the ionization of H<sub>2</sub>:
:H<sub>2</sub> + cosmic ray → {{chem|H|2|+}} + e<sup>−</sup> + cosmic ray
The cosmic ray has so much energy, it is almost unaffected by the relatively small energy transferred to the hydrogen when ionizing an H<sub>2</sub> molecule. In interstellar clouds, cosmic rays leave behind a trail of {{chem|H|2|+}}, and therefore {{chem|H|3|+}}. In laboratories, {{chem|H|3|+}} is produced by the same mechanism in plasma discharge cells, with the discharge potential providing the energy to ionize the H<sub>2</sub>.
==Destruction== The information for this section was also from a paper by Eric Herbst.<ref name="eherbstastro" /> There are many destruction reactions for {{chem|H|3|+}}. The dominant destruction pathway in dense interstellar clouds is by proton transfer with a neutral collision partner. The most likely candidate for a destructive collision partner is the second most abundant molecule in space, [[carbon monoxide|CO]].
:{{chem|H|3|+}} + CO → HCO<sup>+</sup> + H<sub>2</sub>
The significant product of this reaction is HCO<sup>+</sup>, an important molecule for interstellar chemistry. Its strong [[dipole]] and high abundance make it easily detectable by [[radioastronomy]]. {{chem|H|3|+}} can also react with atomic [[oxygen]] to form OH<sup>+</sup> and H<sub>2</sub>.
:{{chem|H|3|+}} + O → OH<sup>+</sup> + H<sub>2</sub>
OH<sup>+</sup> then usually reacts with more H<sub>2</sub> to create further [[hydrogenate]]d molecules.
:OH<sup>+</sup> + H<sub>2</sub> → {{chem|OH|2|+}} + H :{{chem|OH|2|+}} + H<sub>2</sub> → [[Hydronium|{{chem|OH|3|+}}]] + H
At this point, the reaction between {{chem|OH|3|+}} and H<sub>2</sub> is no longer exothermic in interstellar clouds. The most common destruction pathway for {{chem|OH|3|+}} is [[dissociative recombination]], yielding four possible sets of products: H<sub>2</sub>O + H, OH + H<sub>2</sub>, OH + 2H, and O + H<sub>2</sub> + H. While [[water]] is a possible product of this reaction, it is not a very efficient product. Different experiments have suggested that water is created anywhere from 5–33% of the time. Water formation on [[cosmic dust|grains]] is still considered the primary source of water in the interstellar medium.
The most common destruction pathway of {{chem|H|3|+}} in diffuse interstellar clouds is dissociative recombination. This reaction has multiple products. The major product is dissociation into three hydrogen atoms, which occurs roughly 75% of the time. The minor product is H<sub>2</sub> and H, which occurs roughly 25% of the time.
==Ortho/Para-H<sub>3</sub><sup>+</sup>== [[Image:H3+&H2.svg|thumb|350px|A collision of ortho-{{chem|H|3|+}} and para-H<sub>2</sub>.]] The most abundant molecule in dense interstellar clouds is H<sub>2</sub>. When a {{chem|H|3|+}} molecule collides with H<sub>2</sub>, stoichiometrically there is no net yield. However, a proton transfer still can take place, which can potentially change the total [[spin (physics)|nuclear spin]] of the two molecules depending on the nuclear spins of the protons. Two different spin configurations for {{chem|H|3|+}} are possible, called ortho and para. Ortho-{{chem|H|3|+}} has all three proton spins parallel, yielding a total nuclear spin of {{sfrac|3|2}}. Para-{{chem|H|3|+}} has two proton spins parallel while the other is anti-parallel, yielding a total nuclear spin of {{sfrac|1|2}}. Similarly, H<sub>2</sub> also has [[Spin isomers of hydrogen|ortho and para states]], with ortho-H<sub>2</sub> having a total nuclear spin 1 and para-H<sub>2</sub> having a total nuclear spin of 0. When an ortho-{{chem|H|3|+}} and a para-H<sub>2</sub> collide, the transferred proton changes the total spins of the molecules, yielding instead a para-{{chem|H|3|+}} and an ortho-H<sub>2</sub>.<ref name="eherbstastro" />
==Spectroscopy== The [[spectroscopy]] of {{chem|H|3|+}} is challenging. The pure rotational spectrum is exceedingly weak.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Watson | first1 = J.K.G | year = 1971 | title = Forbidden rotational spectra of polyatomic molecules | url = | journal = Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy | volume = 40 | issue = 3| pages = 546–544 | doi = 10.1016/0022-2852(71)90255-4 | bibcode = 1971JMoSp..40..536W }}</ref> Ultraviolet light is too energetic and would dissociate the molecule. [[Rovibronic excitation|Rovibronic]] (Infrared) spectroscopy provides the ability to observe {{chem|H|3|+}}. Rovibronic spectroscopy is possible with {{chem|H|3|+}} because one of the [[normal mode|vibrational modes]] of {{chem|H|3|+}}, the ν<sub>2</sub> asymmetric bend mode, has a weak transition dipole moment. Since Oka's initial spectrum,<ref name="Oka1980" /> over 900 [[Absorption spectroscopy|absorption]] lines have been detected in the infrared region. {{chem|H|3|+}} emission lines have also been found by observing the atmospheres of the Jovian planets. {{chem|H|3|+}} emission lines are found by observing molecular hydrogen and finding a line that cannot be attributed to molecular hydrogen.
==Astronomical detection== {{chem|H|3|+}} has been detected in two types of celestial environments: Jovian planets and interstellar clouds. In Jovian planets, it has been detected in the planet's ionospheres, the region where the Sun's high energy radiation ionizes the particles in the atmosphere. Since there is a high level of H<sub>2</sub> in these atmospheres, this radiation can produce a significant amount of {{chem|H|3|+}}. Also, with a broadband source like the Sun, there is plenty of radiation to pump the {{chem|H|3|+}} to higher energy states from which it can relax by stimulated and spontaneous emission.
===Planetary atmospheres=== The detection of the first {{chem|H|3|+}} emission lines was reported in 1989 by Drossart ''et al.'',<ref name="Drossart1989" /> found in the ionosphere of Jupiter. Drossart found a total of 23 {{chem|H|3|+}} lines with a column density of 1.39{{e|9}}/cm<sup>2</sup>. Using these lines, they were able to assign a temperature to the {{chem|H|3|+}} of around {{convert|1100|K|°C|abbr=on}}, which is comparable to temperatures determined from emission lines of other species like H<sub>2</sub>. In 1993, {{chem|H|3|+}} was found in Saturn by Geballe ''et al.''<ref name="Geballe1993" /> and in Uranus by Trafton ''et al.''<ref name="Trafton1993" />
===Molecular interstellar clouds=== {{chem|H|3|+}} was not detected in the interstellar medium until 1996, when Geballe & Oka reported the detection of {{chem|H|3|+}} in two molecular cloud sightlines, GL2136 and W33A.<ref name="Geballe1996" /> Both sources had temperatures of {{chem|H|3|+}} of about {{convert|35|K|°C|0|abbr=on}} and column densities of about 10<sup>14</sup>/cm<sup>2</sup>. Since then, {{chem|H|3|+}} has been detected in numerous other molecular cloud sightlines, such as AFGL 2136,<ref name="McCall1999">{{cite journal|last=McCall|first=B. J.|display-authors=etal |date=1999|title=Observations of {{chem|H|3|+}} in Dense Molecular Clouds|journal=Astrophysical Journal|volume=522|issue=1|pages=338–348|doi=10.1086/307637|bibcode=1999ApJ...522..338M}}</ref> Mon R2 IRS 3,<ref name="McCall1999" /> GCS 3-2,<ref name="mgoto">{{cite journal|last=Goto|first=M.|display-authors=etal |date=2002|title=Absorption Line Survey of {{chem|H|3|+}} toward the Galactic Center Sources I. GCS 3-2 and GC IRS3|journal=Publications of the Astronomical Society of Japan|volume=54Àissue=6|page=951}}</ref> GC IRS 3,<ref name="mgoto" /> and LkHα 101.<ref name="Brittain2004">{{cite journal|last=Brittain|first=S. D.|display-authors=etal |date=2004|title=Interstellar {{chem|H|3|+}} Line Absorption toward LkHα 101|journal=Astrophysical Journal|volume=606|issue=2|pages=911–916|doi=10.1086/383024|bibcode=2004ApJ...606..911B|url=https://works.bepress.com/sean_brittain/7/download/}}</ref>
===Diffuse interstellar clouds=== Unexpectedly, three {{chem|H|3|+}} lines were detected in 1998 by McCall ''et al.'' in the diffuse cloud sightline of Cyg OB2 No. 12.<ref name="McCall1998" /> Before 1998, the density of H<sub>2</sub> was thought to be too low to produce a detectable amount of {{chem|H|3|+}}. McCall detected a temperature of ~{{convert|27|K|°C|0|abbr=on}} and a column density of ~10<sup>14</sup>/cm<sup>2</sup>, the same column density as Geballe & Oka. Since then, {{chem|H|3|+}} has been detected in many other diffuse cloud sightlines, such as GCS 3-2,<ref name="mgoto" /> GC IRS 3,<ref name="mgoto" /> and ζ Persei.<ref name="McCall2004">{{cite journal|last=McCall|first=B. J.|display-authors=etal |date=2003|title=An Enhanced Cosmic-ray Flux towards ζ Persei Inferred from a Laboratory Study of the {{chem|H|3|+}}-e<sup>−</sup> Recombination Rate|journal=Nature|volume=422|issue=6931|doi=10.1038/nature01498|pmid=12673244|arxiv = astro-ph/0302106 |bibcode = 2003Natur.422..500M|pages=500–2 }}</ref>
===Steady-state model predictions=== To approximate the pathlength of {{chem|H|3|+}} in these clouds, Oka<ref name="Oka2006">{{cite journal|last=Oka|first=T.|date=2006|title=Interstellar H3+|journal=[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|PNAS]]|volume=103|issue=33|pages=12235–12242|doi=10.1073/pnas.0601242103|pmid=16894171|pmc=1567864|bibcode = 2006PNAS..10312235O }}</ref> used the steady-state model to determine the predicted number densities in diffuse and dense clouds. As explained above, both diffuse and dense clouds have the same formation mechanism for {{chem|H|3|+}}, but different dominating destruction mechanisms. In dense clouds, proton transfer with CO is the dominating destruction mechanism. This corresponds to a predicted number density of 10<sup>−4</sup> cm<sup>−3</sup> in dense clouds. :''n''({{chem|H|3|+}}) = (''ζ'' / ''k''<sub>CO</sub>)[''n''(H<sub>2</sub>) / ''n''(CO)] ≈ 10<sup>−4</sup>/cm<sup>3</sup> :''n''({{chem|H|3|+}}) = (''ζ'' / ''k''<sub>e</sub>)[''n''(H<sub>2</sub>) / ''n''(C<sup>+</sup>)] ≈ 10<sup>−6</sup>/cm<sup>3</sup> In diffuse clouds, the dominating destruction mechanism is dissociative recombination. This corresponds to a predicted number density of 10<sup>−6</sup>/cm<sup>3</sup> in diffuse clouds. Therefore, since column densities for diffuse and dense clouds are roughly the same order of magnitude, diffuse clouds must have a pathlength 100 times greater than that for dense clouds. Therefore, by using {{chem|H|3|+}} as a probe of these clouds, their relative sizes can be determined.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox historic site | name = Tullygarran ogham stones | native_name = Clocha Oghaim Tulaigh Garráin | native_language = ga | image = |caption= |other_name = Chute Hall Ogham Stoneshttp://www.kerrycoco.ie/en/allservices/planning/codevelopmentplan2009-2015/thefile,2484,en.pdf | elevation = | locmapin = Ireland | coordinates = {{coord|52.275836|N|9.643068|W|display=inline,title}} | location = Tullygarran, [[Tralee]],
[[County Kerry]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] | area = | built = ''c.'' AD 300–800 | architect = | architecture = | governing_body = | owner = private | type = [[ogham]] stones | height = | designation1 = National Monument of Ireland | designation1_offname = Tullygarran Ogham Stones{{cite web|url=https://www.archaeology.ie/sites/default/files/media/pdf/monuments-in-state-care-kerry.pdf|date=4 March 2009|title= National Monuments in State Care: Ownership & Guardianship |accessdate=2017-08-26}} | designation1_date = | designation1_number = 295 }} The '''Tullygarran ogham stones''' are a pair of [[ogham]] stones forming a [[National Monument (Ireland)|National Monument]] located in [[County Kerry]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]].{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=CefHAAAAMAAJ&q=chute+hall+ogham&dq=chute+hall+ogham&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjBt5T9hpnWAhWLKcAKHcMsAdwQ6AEIJTAA|title=Studies in Irish Epigraphy: The Ogham inscriptions of the barony of Corkaguiney and the counties of Mayo, Wicklow, and Kildare|first=Robert Alexander Stewart|last=Macalister|date=9 September 1897|publisher=D. Nutt|via=Google Books}} ==Location== Tullygarran Ogham Stones are located {{Convert|4.2|km}} east of [[Tralee]], near to Chute Hall.http://www.megalithicireland.com/Tullygarran%20Ogham%20Stones%20Kerry.html{{cite web|url=http://landedestates.nuigalway.ie/LandedEstates/jsp/property-show.jsp?id=1918|title=Chute Hall|website=landedestates.nuigalway.ie}} ==History== The stones were discovered in 1848 after a storm uncovered an ancient burial ground overlooking [[Smerwick]] Bay. [[Dayrolles Eveleigh-de-Moleyns, 4th Baron Ventry]] moved them to his home at Chute Hall.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=AMTUAAAAMAAJ&dq=Tullygarran+ogham&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Tullygarran|title=The national monuments of the Irish Free State|first=Irish Free|last=State|date=9 September 2017|publisher=Stationery Office|via=Google Books}} ==Description== The stones are: * Stone 1: reads LUBBAIS MAQQI DUN....S ("of Lubbais son of Dun...s") and stands {{convert|0.96|m}} tall{{cite web|url=http://www.megalithicmonumentsofireland.com/COUNTIES/KERRY/Tullygarran1_OghamStone.html|title=TULLYGARRAN 1 OGHAM STONE/MEGALITHIC MONUMENTS OF IRELAND.COM|first=PIP|last=2012|website=www.megalithicmonumentsofireland.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/archaeology/cisp/database/stone/balig_5.html|title=CISP - BALIG/5|website=www.ucl.ac.uk|accessdate=18 September 2017}} * Stone 2: reads CCICAMINI MAQQ(I) C(A)TTINI ("of Cíchmuine son of Caitne") and stands {{convert|1.02|m}} tall{{cite web|url=http://www.megalithicmonumentsofireland.com/COUNTIES/KERRY/Tullygarran2_OghamStone.html|title=TULLYGARRAN 2 OGHAM STONE/MEGALITHIC MONUMENTS OF IRELAND.COM|first=PIP|last=2012|website=www.megalithicmonumentsofireland.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/archaeology/cisp/database/stone/balig_6.html|title=CISP - BALIG/6|website=www.ucl.ac.uk|accessdate=18 September 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:National Monuments in County Kerry]] [[Category:Ogham inscriptions]] [[Category:Ogham]] [[Category:Obsolete writing systems]] {{ireland-stub}}

{{about}} [[File:WickerCatPole.jpg|right|thumbnail|A handmade wickerwork [[cat tree|''cat tree'']]]] '''Wicker''' is a technique for making products woven from any one of a variety of cane-like materials, a generic name for the materials used in such manufacture, and a term for the items so produced. The word ''wicker'' is believed to be of Scandinavian origin: ''vika'' which means to bend in Swedish, and ''vikker'' meaning willow.<ref name="dictionary">{{Citation |title=The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language |url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/wicker |year=2009 |contribution=Wicker |edition=Fourth |publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company |accessdate=2012-05-19}}</ref> Wicker is traditionally made of material of [[plant]] origin, such as [[rattan]], [[willow]], [[reed (plant)|reed]], and [[bamboo]], but [[synthetic fibers]] are now also used. Wicker is light yet sturdy, making it suitable for items that will be moved often like [[porch]] and [[patio]] furniture.<ref name="alfresia1">{{Cite web |url=https://www.alfresia.co.uk/catalogsearch/result/?q=wicker |title=Wicker |website=Alfresia |publisher=Vale Mill (Rochdale) Ltd. |location=Manchester |access-date=25 February 2017}}</ref> ''Rushwork'' and wickerwork are terms used in [[England]].<ref name="arts">{{Cite book |title=The Forgotten Arts A practical guide to traditional skills |last=Seymour |first=John |date=1984 |publisher=Angus & Robertson Publishers |isbn=0-207-15007-9 |location=page 54 |pages=192}}</ref>
==History== Wicker has been documented as far back as [[ancient Egypt]], made from indigenous "reed and swamp grasses."<ref name=randomhistory>{{Cite web | url = http://www.randomhistory.com/1-50/005furniture.html | title = From Egypt to the American Patio: The History of Wicker Furniture | publisher = Random History | date= 4 May 2007 | accessdate = 11 October 2012}}</ref> Middle-class families could only afford a few pieces, such as small tables.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bergen.org/AAST/Projects/Egypt/egyptian_social.html |title=Ancient Egyptian Social Life: Professions |first=Lisa |last=Kremen |date=29 April 1997 |accessdate=11 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070527133903/http://www.bergen.org/AAST/Projects/Egypt/egyptian_social.html |archivedate=May 27, 2007 }}</ref> However, archaeologists working on the tombs of the wealthy [[pharaoh]]s have uncovered a wider variety of wicker items,<ref name=saunders>{{cite book | last=Saunders | first=Richard | year=1990 |title = Wicker Furniture: A Guide to Restoring and Collecting | publisher=Random House, Inc.}}</ref> including "chests, baskets, wig boxes, and chairs".<ref name=randomhistory/> Wicker even found use in the [[Achaemenid Empire]] on the battlefield, in [[shield]]s.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://classics.mit.edu/Herodotus/history.7.vii.html |title=The History of Herodotus |last=Herodotus}}</ref>
The popularity of wicker passed from ancient Egypt and [[Persia]] to [[ancient Rome]]. Wicker baskets were used to carry items in [[Pompeii]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4695097.stm | date = 18 July 2005 | title = Rare Pompeii dinner set unveiled | first = David | last = Willey | publisher = BBC News | location = Rome | accessdate = 11 October 2012}}</ref> Furniture was manufactured out of wicker in the Roman style.<ref name=randomhistory/> It has been proposed that the extensive use of wicker in the [[Iron Age]] (1200 BC – 400 AD in Europe) may have influenced the development of the woven patterns used in [[Celtic art]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} By the 16th and 17th centuries, wicker was "quite common"<ref name=randomhistory/> in European countries like [[Portugal]], [[Spain]], and England.
Wicker received a boost during the [[Age of Exploration]], when international sea traders returned from [[southeast Asia]] with a species of [[palm tree|palm]] called [[rattan]]. Rattan is stronger than traditional European wicker materials,<ref name=saunders/> although the rattan stem can be separated so the softer inner core can be used for wicker.
The 19th century brought immense popularity for wicker in Europe, England, and North America.<ref name=randomhistory/> It was used outdoors as well as indoors. People in the [[Victorian Era]] believed it to be more sanitary than upholstered furniture.<ref name=randomhistory/> It was inexpensive,<ref name=aiasf>{{cite web | author = American Institute of Architects, San Francisco | title = Victorian Cottage & Wicker Furniture | year = 2012 | url = http://aiasf.org/event/2012/09/11/victorian-cottage-wicker-furniture/ | quote = Wicker, another form of low-priced furniture, attracted even greater interest beginning in the 1850s and soon became a fixture in almost every American setting. Wicker furniture, suitable for parlor, porch or lawn linked the indoors and outdoors. Hundreds of patterns in wicker, mass-produced by dozens of forms across the country, illustrate the range and richness of Victorian fashion.}}</ref> resisted harsh weather and was adaptable to many styles.<ref name=aiasf/>
In the United States, [[Cyrus Wakefield]] began constructing rattan furniture in the 1850s. He first used rattan that had been offloaded from ships, where it was used as ballast,<ref name="saunders" /> but as his designs became well-known, he began importing the material himself.<ref name="randomhistory" /> Wakefield's company became one of the leading industries in wicker furniture;<ref name="randomhistory" /> it later merged with the Heywood Chair Manufacturing Company (a wooden chair company<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.woodysantiques.com/aboutheywoodwakefield/index.asp | title = From Country Store to Modern Furniture: 100 Years of Progress | year = 2008 | accessdate = 11 October 2012}}</ref> that had invented a mechanical process for weaving wicker seats<ref name="randomhistory" />) to form the [[Heywood-Wakefield Company|Heywood-Wakefield]] of [[Gardner, Massachusetts]], one of the oldest and most prominent North American wicker manufacturers.<ref name="randomhistory" />
In recent times, its aesthetic was influenced heavily by the [[Arts and Crafts movement]] at the turn of the 20th century.{{citation needed|date=October 2012}}
Wicker is still a popular material. Antique wicker products are highly sought after by collectors.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.dovetailantiquewicker.com/ |title=Fine American Wicker Furniture |year=2008 |website=Dovetail Antiques |access-date=11 October 2012}}</ref> Reproductions of furniture and accent pieces are also sold for indoor and outdoor use.<ref name="alfresia1" /><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.wickerhomepatiofurniture.com/victorian-wicker-furniture.html |title=Victorian Wicker Furniture |website=Wicker Home & Patio Furniture |access-date=11 October 2012}}</ref> (In North America today, "rattan" and "wicker" are frequently used interchangeably.)<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://wicker-rattanfurniture.com/ |title=Rattan Wicker Furniture Company |publisher=Healthy Lifestyles Inc |access-date=11 October 2012}}</ref> Wickerwork is an important industry in [[Poland]], employing hundreds of skilled workers to create goods for export to western Europe.<ref>{{cite news | title = Poland revives wicker tradition | first=Adam |last=Easton | publisher = BBC News | location=Rudnik-on-San, [[Poland]]| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4739481.stm | accessdate = 11 October 2012}}</ref>
==Manufacture== Natural wicker is well known for its strength and durability, as well as the high level of beauty and comfort that an expert craftsperson can create. Materials used can be any part of a plant, such as the cores of [[Arundo|cane]] or [[rattan]] stalks, or whole thicknesses of plants, as with [[willow]] switches. Other popular materials include [[Phragmites|reed]] and [[bamboo]]. Natural wicker requires maintenance to keep it in good shape.{{citation needed|date=October 2012}}
Wicker can also be made from synthetic materials, or a combination. In furniture, such as benches, chairs, stools and other seating devices, a frame is typically made of stiffer materials, after which more pliant material is woven into the frame to fill it.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.latour-lith.nl/tuinmeubel-blog/wat-is-wicker.html |title=What is wicker? |website=LatourTuinmeubelen |language=Dutch |access-date=11 March 2015}}</ref> In a smaller piece such as a basket, a strengthening frame is not needed so the entire piece is woven from the wicker material.<ref>{{cite web | title = How to Weave a Wicker Basket: A practical guide | first = Jonathan | last = Ridgeon| url = http://www.bushcraft.ridgeonnet.com/basicbasket.htm |accessdate = 11 October 2012}}</ref>
Synthetic types include paper-wrapped high tensile wire (using the [[Lloyd Loom]] process patented in the early 20th century), and [[plastic]] or [[Resin#Synthetic resins|resin]]. The synthetic wickers are often preferred for outdoor use ("all-weather wicker"). The frame material used in these more recent versions includes aluminum.<ref name="alfresia1" />
==Etymology== {{expand section|date=April 2018}} The word wicker is from the [[Middle English]] ''wiker'', of [[North Germanic languages|Scandinavian]] origin.<ref name=dictionary/>
== Image gallery == {{gallery |Image:wicker.balloon.basket.bath.arp.jpg|A wicker [[hot air balloon|balloon]] basket capable of holding 16 passengers |Image:plastic wicker chairs 01.jpg|Plastic-wicker chairs in [[Toronto]] |Image:The worlds biggest wicker basket - Nowy Tomyśl IMG 3338.JPG|World's largest wicker basket, [[Nowy Tomyśl]], Poland |File:Triumph model h motorcycle of around 1914 arp.jpg|Triumph Model H motorcycle with wicker sidecar }}

revision.text:
[[File:Z-tube.svg|right|thumb|200px|Z-tube]] The '''Z-tube''' is an experimental [[Tool|apparatus]] for measuring the [[tensile strength]] of a [[liquid]].
It consists of a Z-shaped tube with open ends, filled with a liquid, and set on top of a spinning table. If the tube were straight, the liquid would immediately fly out one end or the other of the tube as it began to spin. By bending the ends of the tube back towards the center of [[rotation]], a shift of the liquid away from center will result in the [[water level]] in one end of the tube rising and thus increasing the [[pressure]] in that end of the tube, and consequently returning the liquid to the center of the tube. By measuring the [[rotational speed]] and the distance from the center of rotation to the liquid level in the bent ends of the tube, the pressure reduction inside the tube can be calculated.
[[Pressure#Negative pressures|Negative pressures]], (i.e. less than zero absolute pressure, or in other words, [[tension (physics)|tension]]) have been reported using water processed to remove dissolved [[gas]]es.<ref>Smith, Andrew M. [http://jeb.biologists.org/cgi/reprint/157/1/257.pdf "Negative Pressure Generated by Octopus Suckers: A Study of the Tensile Strengths of Water in Nature,"] ''J. exp. Biol.'', 157, 257-271, 1991.</ref> Tensile strengths up to 280 atmospheres have been reported for water in glass.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XjNS6v7q130C&pg=PA255&lpg=PA255&ots=sGiBMDOEe6&dq=spinning+z+tube+cohesion+water | title= Air and water: the biology and physics of life's media}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
